Posts.Content: Yes I have! And I want to share................... It's taken me nearly a year and a lot of wasted money too. I know we are all different but this one works well for me as I have lots of lumpy and sensitive skin under my DIEP reconstructed boob. I've been buying post surgery bras in hope that they would be softer and usually they are fine, but as the day goes on they can feel very tight at the band or under the cups. My new boob is a bit 'under the arm' so this has added to the discomfort as most bras pull me over to the good side and drag on the sensitive one.  These M&S ones seem to be more forgiving and I can wear them all day. You get VAT off at the till too. The only downside for me personally is that they don't cover the mess that used to be my cleavage, but you can't have everything and I may add some lace to correct this problem. The cups are formed so help to even out the fact of one boob being bigger than the other (I don't like wearing my prosthectic, it's too heavy and feels so numb!) , so now I can wear a T shirt and it looks ok. http://www.marksandspencer.com/post-surgery-padded-full-cup-bra-a-e/p/p60086793?mfPartNumber=T331813&carousel=FUNV_RR Good wishes to all of you on here, Sally xx
Posts.Title: I finally found a comfy bra:)

Posts.Content: A friend recommended tonic water with quinine in  (no gin)! I think it's called Fevertree but Schweppes is good too. I mix it with orange juice and it's not too bad for those queasy moments. Also table water crackers to nibble, although I do find sometimes my throat is too dry to be able to swallow much. Just had Fec 3 and taking it easy for a few days.  Best to all,  Sally  "living on the edge of queasiness "
Posts.Title: Struggling to drink recommended fluids after chemotherapy!

Posts.Content: I had my MRI before the surgery, because my lump didn't show up in the mammogram. Another tiny lump was found because of the MRI and it was removed when I had my surgery 27th April.  I guess it won't hurt to ask your oncologist if you should have one? Best of luck on your road to recovery x
Posts.Title: Surgery pushed back a week, surgeon wants MRI beforehand

Posts.Content: I was all ready to go in for my WLE and Lymph node clearance on Wednesday 20th and today I've just had a call to say that they need an MRI beforehand and the department can't fit one in till Friday, so Booo! I have to wait another week for my surgery, I was all geared up and ready too! Apparently my lump didn't show up on the other tests I've had, (Mammo,Bone scan,CT,) although it can be felt quite easily. I guess the surgeon wants to know exactly what he's dealing with before he operates. Also it's the junior doctor strike next week.....I hope that won't affect anything at Charing Cross Hospital:( Hopefully another week won't hurt in the grand scheme of things?
Posts.Title: Surgery pushed back a week, surgeon wants MRI beforehand

Posts.Content: Thanks for your reply, I'm starting to feel less stressed about the delay now. We have to have trust in the professionals don't we, but sometimes it's hard! Now waiting to hear if the surgery will be next Wednesday or later, because of the junior doctor's strike. Hey Ho, on we go.....................
Posts.Title: Surgery pushed back a week, surgeon wants MRI beforehand

Posts.Content: Hi Chloecat45, Thanks, I took your advice about not eating too much before the MRI,and that was no problem. I was prepared for the banging noises, but I think it would be great if the technician could prep you to say that there will be a selection of noises coming at you. I would have loved a countdown to finishing time or someone to just say 'it's just a few more minutes' as I lost all track of time, and kept thinking it was over, then it started again! But all in all, not too bad, now waiting for results and the Op is rebooked for Wednesday 27th with or without the doctors' strike. Let's get on with it!
Posts.Title: Surgery pushed back a week, surgeon wants MRI beforehand

Posts.Content: Thanks for that! Any little comfort or positive note is welcome right now. I'm even paranoid that because of my age (65) I might be pushed back down the queue! Guess I'm a little paranoid
Posts.Title: Surgery pushed back a week, surgeon wants MRI beforehand

Posts.Content: Well I finally came home from the hospital yesterday after a 12 night stay to treat the 3 infections which had lodged in my reconstructed (Diep flap) breast. One of the infections was E. coli . I had 2 surgeries to wash out the bugs and came home with 1 drain still in place. Sadly the boob is very misshapen and slightly dipped rather than full at the cleavage. Most of it is too far round under my arm as well, and gives the impression of just a small boob under my clothing.  (It should be a size 40D but looks about half that) It's still painfully hard in places and I'm hoping this will improve as I can't get comfortable very easily. It seems to fill with pressure, then goes down a little, but too uncomfortable to contemplate a bra. Maybe when the drain is removed I will be able to bear something around my chest but not just yet. I so want to get back to my beloved dance classes, but right now that seems a long way in the future. Hey ho, once I'm healed then I will be facing chemo and more, I have an appointment on Tuesday to meet my oncologist, and I'm just hoping that this setback won't delay my ongoing treatments too much. I'm sorry for my dear husband who has had to listen to all my problems and fears.ive been cheerful for my three boys because I didn't want to spoil their young lives, but I think poor hubby has had to take the strain a lot. Yesterday I cried for the first time since this Cancer came into my life. I think because I have been basically fit and well until now and just moving through the treatments with a goal at the end. Funny how a comparatively small setback can be the tipping point. At least I'm in my own bed now!  Nice to unload a bit, thanks for 'listening' Hope your journeys are going smoothly! Sally
Posts.Title: Diep problems on and on......,

Posts.Content: What a pain! I had my mastectomy and diep recon on 20th June. Came home and did what I was told. At the weekend I had a fever and a big swelling boob and then lots of ghastly red leaking so off to A&E I went. On IV antibiotics then surgery for cleanout and removal of small patch of necrosis on boob. That was Monday and today is Wednesday so when I woke up with a hot boob again and an infection at the site of the breast drain I kind of new it was not over yet! Back to surgery tomorrow (Thursday) for more cleaning and the poor old boob is now the shape of a big fat squashed donut in ever changing shades of all the most ghastly colours.  I have been contemplating a name for this badly behaved breast-like thing and last night it came to me! From now on she will be called Miss Piggy as she has a snout and is very demanding Ouch!
Posts.Title: Diep problems on and on......,

Posts.Content: Well! Nine months of relentless treatment came to an abrupt stop last Wednesday after my final radiotherapy treatment. I have a couple of follow ups still to come but right now it's quite hard to get used to the idea that it is FINALLY over! I'm physically not completely 'settled' as my Diep recon boob (surgery was June 2016) still has lumps and bumps that change shape and it's pretty tight around the chest even when I'm not wearing a bra. I think the chemo (FEC-T which finished end of November) has had the longest hangover and the nails which haven't fallen off are still held on with sticking plaster. My hair is coming on well though and instead of my long red hair I have an almost white mini mohawk, only half an inch but I just about can brush it into shape:) I have been told that radiotherapy will keep working away in the areas treated for another two weeks or so. I haven't had a bad reaction to it, just still a bit red and slightly 'rashy' looking. I got a horrid cold this week, maybe my immune system is still struggling, also have developed a beastly horrible toothache, the cause of which has not really been found by my dentist. He prescribed antibiotics and I can't  eat on that side as that's what sets it off. I've worried myself sick about this toothache because I have had two sessions of  IV Bisphosphonates (Zometa) . My dentist and BCN both informed me that I can never have a tooth pulled out ....ever, and that is scary when you are in pain. This is because of a a risk of osteonecrosis of the jaw when on Zometa which sounds terrifying. The risk is always there even if you stop the Zometa apparently because it stays in your bones. But then the Zometa can help prevent spread to the bones in post menopausal women so there are pros and cons. So it's over but in some ways it's not over, guess I'm not alone in feeling this. Best wishes to all ladies and gents out there who have been hit by this beastly thing. May your treatment and care be good and successful and your after effects few x (My next mammo and MRI will be in March, my one year anniversary)
Posts.Title: I've finished all of the treatment!

Posts.Content: Thanks for the good wishes! My dentist put me on antibiotics in case of an infection even though he couldn't see anything but hooray! my tooth seems to have settled today. I expect that my immune system is still weak after the treatments. Karen, make sure you have a checkup with the dentist before you have the bisphosphonates as once you've had them your options for any major tooth treatments become very limited. I wasn't alerted to this until after I'd had the first two IVs with bisphosphonates. My third one was cancelled when I reported my toothache and I was sent straight away for a panoramic jaw x-ray and told to make an urgent appointment with my dentist for a checkup and a letter to show the health of my teeth. So I never had the third one and now the treatments will be every six months. I think slippers for Summer is a very practical idea:) Good luck with the rest of your treatments xx
Posts.Title: I've finished all of the treatment!

Posts.Content: I had a mastectomy and Diep at the end of June 2016. In early July I unfortunately developed some Infections in the Diep breast so was readmitted to hospital for 10 days where I had 2 more surgeries to wash out the infections. My poor boob is very scarred in what should be the cleavage area, but at least it passes for a boob when I'm dressed. It seemed fine and settled until around 30th December when it developed 2 lumps and also some swelling so it's tight when I put my arm in certain positions.The oncologist thought it may be lymphodema and scar thickening. I started my planned radiotherapy on Jan 3rd for 15 sessions. I had an ultrasound on Friday 'just to see'. I'm used to this boob causing me trouble but lumps are always scary!
Posts.Title: Recovery after mastectomy/diep

Posts.Content: Thanks for the info and advice.  I'll take your advice and yes there will be dancing again soon (gently) Sally  x
Posts.Title: It worries me that my chemo is delayed because of Diep flap infec...

Posts.Content: Hi all, Well it's been more than 5 weeks since my Mastectomy and Diep flap reconstruction to the left breast. I posted on here that I went back to hospital for 11 days due to infections in breast. I came out almost 2 weeks ago and still the breast patch (not sure what to call it but where the areola was) is draining a mixture of 'liquid fat' and 'red liquid'. The plastics dressing clinic fitted me with a stoma bag over my breast which although kind of gross, does at least allow me to deal with it without unpeeling the dressing all the time. There is a small stopper which I can undo to empty the bag. I have been instructed to squeeze and press the breast to help the flow of liquid to come out. The doctor told me last week that I'm not out of the woods yet, meaning that although the antibiotics are finished, there is still some infection to be seen. My worry is that how will the skin ever heal if there is constant drainage through the breast patch? How will I ever be ready for chemo? When I ask the chemo question at the hospital I'm not surprised that the answer is 'well you have to heal first'. I guess what I want to hear is 'a delay to chemo won't be detrimental to you in the great scheme of things' Then I could stop obsessing about it........................................!
Posts.Title: It worries me that my chemo is delayed because of Diep flap infec...

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn I'm actually 65, still got those dense breasts ( well one anyway )! I had 2 out of 18 lymph nodes affected. But one was extra large at 28mm. Yes Fec X 3 and T X 3 then some kind of 10 year hormone suppressing meds , not sure which as yet.  I didn't come up as borderline chemo because of the large lymph node. Hope this makes sense! Sally
Posts.Title: It worries me that my chemo is delayed because of Diep flap infec...

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn and thanks for the reassurance! In answer to your question I had lumpectomy mid April and node clearance at the same time . On follow up I was told that the margins were not clear and there was quite a lot of dcis seen with the microscope which is why mastectomy was recommended. Im hormone positive and Her negative by the way. They didn't recommend mastectomy for my other breast though, just careful watching and MRI yearly as I have dense breasts and mammogram does not show up any lumps or changes.  Best wishes  Sally
Posts.Title: It worries me that my chemo is delayed because of Diep flap infec...

Posts.Content: Hi there, I'm new to this group and have a diagnosis of Grade 2 mixed ductal/mucinous carcinoma (12mm lump) and I'm scheduled for WLE &  ALND on 20th April. I'm age 65 and my boobs are not what they used to be, but I love to dance and with the help of a good sports bra I can do my Tap and Belly dance classes without scaring the young ones too much:) I want to order some post op bras. I would welcome advice as to whether to buy a size or two larger than my usual 38D? I'm not expecting to be dancing for a while, but I would love to hear if any of you have managed to get back to active exercise and roughly how long it could take to feel able to do so? Thanks x
Posts.Title: Post Op bra size?

Posts.Content: Hi Julia, Thanks for the good advice and I'm glad I've found this website and forum! Sally x
Posts.Title: Post Op bra size?

Posts.Content: Thanks June, Yes 'fearing the worst' is perhaps the most terrible part of it! Each treatment has it's own possibly life threatening or changing potential side effects and we all have to look some or all of them in the eye don't we? Because not taking it on would be far far worse:( Have a great weekend, Best wishes Sally x
Posts.Title: It's been a year and I'm in the clear!

Posts.Content: Hi all, Just had to share my one year anniversary results with you all......My annual MRI and mammogram results came in clear and today I had a meeting with the consultant who had given me the horrid news last March. After one more physical exam he declared me in the clear and so I think I can now call myself a Neddy (No Evidence of Disease Detected) . I tearfully gave him a hug:) It's been a tough year (WLE, Mastectomy with DIEP reconstruction,then 3 infections and consequently 2 extra surgeries, Chemo, Rads, Letrozole and Zometa...the works!) Resulting in an 'almost' boob but horribly disfigured cleavage from the fat necrosis and some ongoing discomfort with the boob. Also I have some Tinnitus and slight deafness from the chemo, but it's bearable, fingers crossed. But I am HAPPY and relieved it's over and I'm looking forward to good times ahead. I wish all ladies and gents who are going through this S**T the very best to get through the treatment and good luck for your futures. I'm celebrating by heading off to a tap class today then a meal tonight with my lovely husband who has suffered a lot this year too! Cocktails will be on the menu......Cheers! Sally xxx
Posts.Title: It's been a year and I'm in the clear!

Posts.Content: Hi there, sorry to hear about your mum. I am writing from the point of view of a mum with cancer. My three boys are grown up and living their own lives but the worst thing for me when I had my diagnosis was having to tell them . All I want is not to spoil their lives. So I'm happy that they are totally there for me if I need them, but they are going out  and enjoying their lives too. I love to see their happy times on Facebook ! I want them to just carry on and don't feel guilty, cry if you want too sometimes but live your life. I am 'strangely' calm and just getting on with it right now. We'll cross each bridge as it comes.  When people have said to me how are you not panicking all the time, I say 'would it help?' The answer is always no Love to you x
Posts.Title: Mother diagnosed with breast cancer and I'm terrified

Posts.Content: Hi all, this is a semi humorous post and it helps to keep me busy until my surgery in three days time!  I received a letter today from the Consultant Surgeon who did my WLE and axillary nodes clearance in April. The letter was the standard confirmation in writing of what we had discussed in clinic early May, ie further surgery and recon. He then went on to say that he recommends a "Competition Left Mastectomy" and later in the letter to assess my suitability for an "Abnormal DIEP flap reconstruction." I have to admit that with the surgery booked in for 20th June ie in 3 days time, I was slightly disturbed until I twigged that he must have dictated this to a computerised device and the 'Abnormal DIEP flap' should read 'Abdominal DIEP flap' Haven't quite worked out what the Competition Left Mastectomy translates to yet, but as long as I win the contest on Monday I will be happy:) Starting to feel a bit trembly now, having waited 6 weeks for this I can't wait to get it over with! My current mantra is: Keep Calm and Just Turn Up (on Monday)
Posts.Title: This worried me at first, now I'm smiling:)

Posts.Content: Thanks! Looks like you are entering too, so all the best to you on Monday :)  You might like to know that six weeks on from my lymph node clearance, my arm and shoulder are totally fine and I've been back to yoga,tap and belly dance classes for a few weeks.  I have to say that gentle dancing classes (especially belly dancing) are a lot more fun and interesting than those boring exercises the leaflet suggests! They are important of course in the early days, and they work better if you put some music on to do them to.............. xxxx
Posts.Title: This worried me at first, now I'm smiling:)

Posts.Content: I might be giggling when I meet the surgeon on Monday:)
Posts.Title: This worried me at first, now I'm smiling:)

Posts.Content: Thanks for your replies, I took the advice and called them. As helsbels found they told me it classed as routine screening. My insurer is called Get Going and the cost of this single trip for a couple is £44.72. My husband takes Blood pressure pills and I also have underactive thyroid medication and Asthma, plus he is 68 and I am 66 so is probably a reasonable enough price for insurance:) Soooooo looking forward to some sunshine! Best wishes to all, Sally x
Posts.Title: Travel insurance medical screening question

Posts.Content: Hi all, I've booked a holiday to Cyprus in May and arranged travel insurance but woke up in the night worrying that I may have misunderstood one of the medical screening questions as follows: "Are you currently on a waiting list for treatment or investigation? " (I answered No) I finished my treatment for BC (Surgery/Chemo/Rads) at end of January but I have received an appointment for an MRI and Mammogram in early March which is around the one year anniversary of my original diagnosis.  Do you think these appointments count as a "Yes" or a "No" to the above question?
Posts.Title: Travel insurance medical screening question
